bestBHT.bht: Paul vehemently denies the charges presented by the Jews, insisting on his innocence against accusations of violating Jewish law, desecrating the temple, and committing treason against Caesar. In his defense, he makes it clear that he has not sinned or offended either the Jewish law or Caesar. Able to dispel the falsehoods of the charges, Paul's thorough response convinces the judge of his innocence. This defense, resembling his previous one before Felix, highlights Paul's complete denial and the lack of evidence provided against him.

Henry Alford: 8.] These were the three principal charges to which the “many and grievous complaints” of the Jews referred.
Albert Barnes: While he answered ... - See this answer more at length in Acts 24:10-21. As the accusations against him were the same now as then, he made to them the same reply.
Marvin Vincent: Have I offended [ημαρτον] . See on the kindred noun aJmartia, sin, Matthew 1:21.
Philip Schaff: No doubt repeating in the main the arguments briefly reported in the first trial before the Procurator Felix, adding, probably, an indignant denial, and one that convinced his judge respecting the alleged treason against the emperor and the state.
Some years later, perhaps five or six, it was upon this accusation of treason that Paul’s enemies no doubt finally compassed their purpose.
After his Second Epistle to Timothy, over the apostle’s life and work there falls a great hush, which tells too surely its own story.
Archibald T. Robertson: Paul sums up the charges under the three items of law of the Jews, the temple, the Roman state (Caesar).
Paul's denial is complete and no proof had been presented.
John Gill: As he was allowed by the Roman laws to do, he pleaded his own cause, and showed the falsehood of the charges exhibited against him.
Neither against the law of the Jews; the law of Moses, whether moral, ceremonial, or judicial; not the moral law, that he was a strict observer of, both before and since his conversion.
Nor yet against Caesar, have I offended at all; for he was charged with sedition.
John Wesley: While he answered — To a general charge a general answer was sufficient.

These charges can be summarized as violations of Jewish law, desecration of the temple, and treason against Caesar. He refutes the falsehoods of the charges and provides a comprehensive response, similar to his earlier defense before Felix. The false accusation of treason against him ultimately leads to his imprisonment and the subsequent silence about his life and work. His defense, dispelling the charges, was enough to convince the judge of his innocence.
